text.headline: Artist
text.text:
Renaissance artists, particularly painters, worked with a small army of pigment-grinders, paint-preparers, apprentices, and journeymen simultaneously learning the ropes of draftsmanship, portraiture, and history painting. The collaborative nature of the business comes to the fore in Stradanus’s Invention of Oil Painting as the central painter clearly cannot do everything by himself. He is focused on putting the final touches on a painting—possibly one of several copies for sale, all featuring Saint George and the Dragon—while leaving the bulk of the preparatory work, and even parts of the composition to his assistants. As a painter himself, Stradanus likely felt invested in including the labor and methods of painting in his Nova Reperta series—not only in this plate, but also in another engraving that depicts one of the raw materials for oil paint: the Invention of Olive Oil.

Main image: Philips Galle, after Johannes Stradanus, Color Olivi (Invention of Oil Painting), from Nova Reperta (New Discoveries), c. 1588. Engraving, Newberry Library. See the original Newberry album here.

media.credit: After Sebastiaan Vrancx, Blazoen van het Sint-Lucasgilde met de Heilige Lucas die Maria schildert (Blazon of the Saint-Luke Guild with Saint Luke Painting the Virgin Mary), 1620-21. Engraving, Rijksmuseum .

text.headline: Artist Guilds
text.text: The inscription below Stradanus's engraving incorrectly claims that early fifteenth-century Belgian artist Jan van Eyck invented oil colors, a notion likely devised by Italian painter Giorgio Vasari for his 1550 Lives of the Artists. The standing artist could also embody Saint Luke, the patron saint of civic  artist guilds, including one in Stradanus’s native Antwerp. This workshop reflects Northern practices, and the coat of arms above the door in fact represents the Antwerp shield. Vrancx’s engraving, above, also represents this “blazon” or guild coat of arms, and includes a border with the same shield and tools of the trade that we can see in Stradanus’s artist’s workshop, surrounding a traditional view of Luke at work painting the Virgin Mary and Christ Child.

media.credit: (Heinrich Vogtherr I, Skillful Little Book for All Painters (Libellus artificiosus omnibus pictoribus),, 1539, Newberry Library.

text.headline: Hands are the hardest
text.text: Practice made perfect, but budding artists did not always have a live model available when they wanted to practice drawing body parts and other common motifs. In Stradanus’s engraving, an apprentice copies eye after eye onto an erasable tablet, while another copies a sculptural head. They could also have used a pattern book like the one featured here by Heinrich Vogtherr the Elder. Its woodcuts offered a wide variety of depictions of hands, heads, and even arms and armor for artisans of all stripes. Vogtherr’s own son helped with this publication, underlining the need for a steady stream of apprentices in a busy workshop.

text.headline: Blazon of color
text.text: The arts of drawing (disegno) and color (colore) have been considered complementary but separate artistic achievements since antiquity, when Apelles and Zeuxis drew the most perfect line and illusionistic painting respectively. With the flourishing of oil painting during the Renaissance, color gained even more meaning. This popular treatise on color broke different tinctures (heraldic colors) down into a hierarchy of metallic and jewel-tones (gules for red; azure for blue; sable for black). Another spelling of “gules” (“guelles”), meaning red, can be seen in the circular marker taken from this booklet. Gold and silver could be applied in thin sheets of metal leaf, or more impressively, approximated in paint; others pigments were ground from minerals, suspended in oil to become paint, and pre-mixed into appropriate shades on a palette.
